taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Inhabits lower courses of the larger rivers.  Free swimming species found near the surface.  Nocturnal, plus active during dusk and dawn.  Feeds on smaller fish.  The male is recognizable by his thick, ossified maxillary barbels and by the first few rays of the anal fin which are fused, supporting the urogenyla tube that runs along the anterior border to the tip of the rays (Ref. 6868).  This fish comprises the majority of the catches in the fish nets and is especially captured during the rainy season which is its reproductive period.  Occurs less frequently in flood zones, prefers eroded zones where it appears in large numbers (Ref. 27188).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Lower Amazon and Tocantins rivers northward to Marowijne River.  Possibly also Rupununi River in Guyana and Negro River in Brazil.
dataObjects.references: Ferraris, C.J. Jr. 2003 Auchenipteridae (Driftwood catfishes). p. 470-482. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 37098)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Lower Amazon and Tocantins rivers northward to Marowijne River; possibly also Rupununi River, Guyana and Negro River, Brazil: Brazil and French Guiana.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Environment
dataObjects.description: pelagic; freshwater; pH range: 6.7 - 7.2; dH range: 7 - 16

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TrophicStrategy
dataObjects.description: Inhabits lower courses of the larger rivers.  Free swimming species found near the surface.  Nocturnal, plus active during dusk and dawn. The male is recognizable by his thick, ossified maxillary barbels and by the first few rays of the anal fin which are fused, supporting the urogenyla tube that runs along the anterior border to the tip of the rays (Ref. 6868).  Feeds mainly on insects and some crustaceans and fish (Ref. 27188).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Cucullanus Infestation 5. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)
